results.input: Chen Quanguo - Xinjiang Party Secretary

output.name: Chen Quanguo
output.position: Xinjiang Party Secretary
output.key_abuses: Implemented a comprehensive surveillance, detention, and indoctrination program in Xinjiang targeting Uyghurs and other ethnic minorities. Oversaw the construction of mass detention camps where torture and abuse were reported. He also intensified security operations in Tibet to tighten control over Tibetan ethnic minorities.

key_actions.action: Sanctioned by US under Global Magnitsky Act

detailed_responsibilities: Architect of mass internment camp system in Xinjiang
Implemented "vocational training centers" holding 1-3 million Uyghurs
Previously implemented similar tactics in Tibet (2011-2016)
Expanded surveillance and "grid management" systems

results.input: Zhu Hailun - Xinjiang Security Chief

output.name: Zhu Hailun
output.position: Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of the People's Congress of Xinjiang
output.key_abuses: Zhu Hailun is held responsible for serious human rights violations in Xinjiang, particularly the large-scale arbitrary detentions of Uyghurs and other Muslim ethnic minorities. He was a key political figure in overseeing and implementing a comprehensive program of surveillance, detention, and indoctrination. He has been described as the 'architect' of this program.
detailed_responsibilities: Head of Xinjiang Political and Legal Affairs Commission
Oversaw security apparatus and detention system
Signed documents ordering mass detentions
Named in Xinjiang Police Files

results.input: Wang Junzheng - XPCC Secretary

output.name: Wang Junzheng
output.position: Party Secretary of the Tibet Autonomous Region
output.key_abuses: Wang Junzheng is linked to serious human rights abuses against ethnic minorities in Xinjiang, including arbitrary detention and severe physical abuse. These abuses occurred during his tenure as Secretary of the Party Committee of the Xinjiang Production and Construction Corps (XPCC).

key_actions.action: Sanctioned by US for Xinjiang role

detailed_responsibilities: Former Deputy Secretary of Xinjiang during camp expansion
Now implementing similar policies in Tibet
Overseeing forced labor transfer programs
Expanding surveillance infrastructure

results.input: Wang Mingshan - Xinjiang Public Security Director

output.name: Wang Mingshan
output.position: Deputy Director of the Standing Committee of the Party Committee of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region
output.key_abuses: As the former Director of the Xinjiang Public Security Bureau, Wang Mingshan was responsible for the implementation of a large-scale surveillance, detention, and indoctrination program targeting Uyghurs and other Muslim minorities. He oversaw the use of the 'Integrated Joint Operations Platform,' a big data system used to track and detain individuals, leading to arbitrary detentions and other severe human rights abuses.

results.input: Carrie Lam - Hong Kong Chief Executive

output.name: Carrie Lam
output.position: Former Chief Executive of Hong Kong
output.key_abuses: As Chief Executive of Hong Kong, Carrie Lam was sanctioned for her role in implementing Beijing's policies that suppress freedom and democratic processes. She pushed for an extradition bill to mainland China, which triggered widespread protests, and was involved in the implementation of the National Security Law, which undermines Hong Kong's autonomy.

key_actions.action: Refused independent inquiry into police violence

detailed_responsibilities: Introduced extradition bill sparking 2019 protests
Oversaw implementation of National Security Law
Presided over mass arrests of pro-democracy figures
Closed Apple Daily and independent media

results.input: John Lee - Hong Kong Chief Executive

output.name: John Lee
output.position: Chief Executive of Hong Kong
output.key_abuses: John Lee is accused of undermining Hong Kong's autonomy and restricting the freedom of its residents. He played a key role in the implementation of the National Security Law, which has been used to crack down on dissent and political opposition.

key_actions.action: As Security Secretary, oversaw police response to protests

detailed_responsibilities: Former Security Secretary who oversaw 2019 protest crackdown
Implemented Article 23 national security legislation
Continued prosecution of pro-democracy activists
Expanded surveillance and censorship

results.input: Teresa Cheng - Hong Kong Justice Secretary

output.name: Teresa Cheng
output.position: Hong Kong Justice Secretary
output.key_abuses: As Hong Kong's Secretary for Justice, Teresa Cheng was a key figure in the implementation of the National Security Law, which has been criticized for undermining the city's autonomy and suppressing freedoms of expression and assembly.
output.current_status: Active as secretary-general of the International Organization for Mediation.

results.input: Erick Tsang - Hong Kong Secretary for Constitutional Affairs

output.name: Erick Tsang
output.position: Secretary for Constitutional and Mainland Affairs
output.key_abuses: Undermining Hong Kong's autonomy and restricting the freedom of expression or assembly of the citizens of Hong Kong.

results.input: Chris Tang - Hong Kong Security Secretary

output.name: Chris Tang
output.position: Secretary for Security
output.key_abuses: Chris Tang is sanctioned by the U.S. for his role in undermining Hong Kong's autonomy and restricting the freedom of expression or assembly of its citizens. As the former Commissioner of Police, he was responsible for the crackdown on pro-democracy protests, including the siege of Hong Kong Polytechnic University and the arrest of hundreds of protesters. He has been a vocal supporter of the National Security Law, which has been used to suppress dissent and political opposition in Hong Kong.

results.input: Xia Baolong - Hong Kong Affairs Director

output.name: Xia Baolong
output.position: Director of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Office of the State Council
output.key_abuses: Designated for being a leader or official of a government entity that has engaged in, or whose members have engaged in, actions or policies that threaten the peace, security, stability, or autonomy of Hong Kong.

results.input: Luo Huining - Hong Kong Liaison Office Director

output.name: Luo Huining
output.position: Hong Kong Liaison Office Director
output.key_abuses: Undermining Hong Kong's autonomy and restricting the freedom of expression or assembly of the citizens of Hong Kong. He was designated by the U.S. for being a leader of a government entity whose members have engaged in actions or policies that threaten the peace, security, stability, or autonomy of Hong Kong.
output.current_status: Active in Beijing, leading a party campaign to study and implement Xi Jinping's political ideology.

results.input: Zheng Yanxiong - Hong Kong National Security Office

output.name: Zheng Yanxiong
output.position: Former Director of the Liaison Office of the Central People's Government in the Hong Kong SAR
output.key_abuses: As the inaugural Director of the Office for Safeguarding National Security in Hong Kong, he was responsible for implementing the National Security Law, which has been used to undermine Hong Kong's autonomy and restrict the freedom of expression and assembly.
output.current_status: Removed from Hong Kong posts in May 2025, new role unconfirmed.

results.input: Wu Yingjie - Tibet Party Secretary

output.name: Wu Yingjie
output.position: Tibet Autonomous Region (TAR) Party Secretary (2016-2021)
output.key_abuses: During his tenure as TAR Party Secretary, Wu Yingjie directed stability policies that resulted in serious human rights abuses, including extrajudicial killings, physical abuse, arbitrary arrests, mass detentions, forced sterilization, coerced abortion, restrictions on religious and political freedoms, and the torture of prisoners.
output.current_status: Under investigation for corruption in China, sentenced to a suspended death sentence.

results.input: Pema Thinley - Tibet Government Chairman

output.name: Pema Thinley
output.position: Vice-Chairperson, 13th National People's Congress Standing Committee
output.us_sanctions: Yes - December 7, 2020 (under EO 13936, as NPC vice-chairperson involved in Hong Kong NSL)
output.key_abuses: Sanctioned under EO 13936 as NPC Vice-Chairperson for involvement in the passage and implementation of the Hong Kong National Security Law. Previously, as Chairman of the Tibet Autonomous Region (2010-2013) and Chairman of the TAR People's Congress (2013-2018), he led the harsh crackdown against the 2008 protests in Lhasa and implemented restrictive policies toward Tibetans.

results.input: Che Dalha - TAR Party Secretary

output.name: Che Dalha (Qi Zhala)
output.position: Party Secretary of the Tibet Autonomous Region (since 2021)
output.key_abuses: As TAR Party Secretary since October 2021, has continued and expanded the coercive labor transfer programs, religious restrictions, and surveillance systems in Tibet. Under his leadership, Tibetan monasteries face ongoing restrictions on religious practice, Tibetan language education has been further marginalized in schools, and the network of 'convenience police stations' has expanded. Continues Wu Yingjie's policies of political indoctrination campaigns in monasteries and residential surveillance.

results.input: Zhang Qingli - Former TAR Party Secretary (2005-2011)

output.name: Zhang Qingli
output.position: Former Party Secretary of the Tibet Autonomous Region (2005-2011)
output.key_abuses: TAR Party Secretary during the March 2008 Tibetan uprising. Ordered the violent military crackdown on protesters across the Tibetan Plateau, resulting in an estimated 100-220 deaths and over 5,000 detained. Called the Dalai Lama 'a wolf in monk's robes, a devil with a human face' in official rhetoric. Imposed martial law conditions including communications blackouts, mass arrests, and forced patriotic education campaigns in monasteries. Under his tenure, self-immolations by Tibetans began as a form of protest against religious suppression.
output.current_status: Retired - formerly Vice Chairman of CPPCC (2018-2023)

results.input: Chen Mingguo - Xinjiang Public Security Bureau Director

output.name: Chen Mingguo
output.position: Former Director of the Xinjiang Public Security Bureau
output.key_abuses: As Director of the Xinjiang Public Security Bureau, Chen Mingguo is held responsible for serious human rights abuses, including arbitrary detentions and degrading treatment inflicted upon Uyghurs and people from other Muslim ethnic minorities in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region.

results.input: Liu Jianchao - CCP International Liaison

output.name: Liu Jianchao
output.position: Head of the International Department of the Chinese Communist Party
output.key_abuses: Liu Jianchao is a key figure in China's 'Operation Fox Hunt,' a global campaign of transnational repression. He is accused of overseeing the kidnapping, trapping, and 'persuasion to return' of thousands of overseas Chinese, in violation of international human rights standards and the sovereignty of other nations.
output.current_status: Detained and under investigation in China since August 2025. Last public appearance July 29, 2025 in Algeria. Taken in for questioning by CCDI (Central Commission for Discipline Inspection) upon return to Beijing.

results.input: Wang Yi - Foreign Minister

output.name: Wang Yi
output.position: Member of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee, Director of the Office of the Central Commission for Foreign Affairs, and Foreign Minister
output.key_abuses: As Foreign Minister, Wang Yi is the international face of the CCP and is responsible for defending and implementing its policies, including those related to human rights abuses in Xinjiang, Hong Kong, and Tibet. He has been a vocal critic of other countries for raising human rights concerns and has actively worked to counter international pressure on China.

key_actions.action: Threatened Philippines over South China Sea

detailed_responsibilities: Chief diplomat defending CCP human rights record
Promotes "wolf warrior" diplomacy
Denies genocide and repression allegations
Threatens countries over Taiwan, Tibet, Xinjiang

results.input: Zhao Kezhi - Public Security Minister

output.name: Zhao Kezhi
output.position: Minister of Public Security
output.key_abuses: As Minister of Public Security, Zhao Kezhi was responsible for the mass internment and surveillance of Uyghurs in Xinjiang, including the 'strike hard' campaign and the creation of a DNA database. He was also involved in the suppression of protests in Hong Kong and oversaw the 'Residential Surveillance at a Designated Location' (RSDL) system, a form of secret detention that has been described as amounting to torture.

key_actions.action: Directed response to Hong Kong protests

detailed_responsibilities: Oversaw national police and security apparatus
Responsible for transnational repression operations
Directed Fox Hunt and Sky Net operations
Oversaw expansion of surveillance technology

results.input: Guo Shengkun - Political-Legal Affairs Commission

output.name: Guo Shengkun
output.position: Secretary of the Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission
output.key_abuses: As Secretary of the Central Political and Legal Affairs Commission, Guo Shengkun oversaw the Chinese Communist Party's security and legal apparatus. The European Parliament has called for sanctions against him for his role in the systematic human rights violations in the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region.

results.input: Xi Jinping - General Secretary of CCP

output.name: Xi Jinping
output.position: General Secretary of CCP, President of PRC, Chairman of CMC
output.key_abuses: Ultimate authority over all CCP policies including mass detention in Xinjiang, crackdown in Hong Kong, cultural repression in Tibet. Architect of constitutional changes removing term limits. Oversees Belt and Road Initiative and military expansion. Responsible for crackdown on civil society, lawyers, and journalists.

key_actions.action: Imposed Hong Kong National Security Law

detailed_responsibilities: Ultimate authority over all CCP policies including Xinjiang, Hong Kong, Tibet
Architect of "Xi Jinping Thought" and constitutional changes removing term limits
Oversees Belt and Road Initiative and military expansion
Responsible for crackdown on civil society, lawyers, journalists
